habitat: Cool, moist conifer and mixed forests; common in spruce–fir and northern hardwood–conifer communities, often on well-drained slopes and also on colder/wetter flats.
description: A fragrant, narrow-crowned evergreen with flat needles and resin blisters on the bark. In WMNF it is a signature spruce–fir component, especially at higher elevations and in colder valleys.
ecology: Provides dense winter cover for wildlife and nesting habitat for birds; contributes needles and woody debris that shape acidic, mossy forest floors typical of spruce–fir systems.
conservationStatus: Common in northern New England; no special status noted (species-level).

sources.title: USFS FEIS species review: Abies balsamea

habitat: Spruce–fir forests and mixed northern forests; common on cool, moist sites and higher-elevation slopes and ridges in WMNF.
description: A long-lived evergreen spruce with short, sharp needles and scaly bark. Red spruce is a dominant canopy tree across many WMNF spruce–fir landscapes.
ecology: Key canopy species in spruce–fir systems; provides cover and food web support via insects and seeds; contributes to cold, humid microclimates important for boreal-associated plants and animals.
conservationStatus: Common regionally; some high-elevation spruce–fir habitats are conservation priorities as southern-edge communities.

habitat: Cool ravines, shaded slopes, streamside forests, and mixed woods; often on moist, acidic or rocky sites.
description: A shade-tolerant evergreen with flat needles and small pendant cones, forming cool, dark stands in ravines and on moist slopes.
ecology: Creates shaded, cool microclimates; evergreen cover used by deer and many birds; hemlock stands influence stream temperatures and habitat structure.
conservationStatus: Regionally threatened by hemlock woolly adelgid; local impacts vary.

habitat: Forests and woodlands across a wide range of soils; common at lower to mid elevations including mixed forests and old field succession.
description: A tall conifer with soft needles in bundles of five and elongated cones. Often forms mixed stands and is prominent in lower-elevation WMNF edges and valleys.
ecology: Provides mast (seeds) and structural habitat; large pines offer nesting sites and windbreak effects; early successional stands can develop after disturbance.
conservationStatus: Common; subject to pests/diseases (e.g., blister rust, weevil) in parts of its range.

habitat: Northern hardwood and northern hardwood–conifer forests on well-drained, fertile slopes; common in WMNF mid-elevations.
description: A dominant hardwood of northern forests, known for brilliant fall color and (regionally) maple syrup production.
ecology: Key canopy species in northern hardwood stands; provides leaf litter that supports rich forest soils and spring wildflowers; seeds and buds are wildlife food.
conservationStatus: Common regionally; local impacts may include beech bark disease associates in mixed stands and climate stress over time.

habitat: Northern hardwood and mixed forests; common on well-drained slopes, often with sugar maple and yellow birch.
description: A smooth-barked hardwood producing beech nuts. In WMNF it’s a classic northern hardwood associate.
ecology: Beech nuts are a significant mast resource for wildlife; beech thickets can form after disturbance or disease; provides cavities and den sites as trees age.
conservationStatus: Widespread but affected regionally by beech bark disease.

habitat: Cool, moist northern hardwood and mixed forests; common on slopes and ravines, often with sugar maple and beech.
description: A northern hardwood with distinctive bark that can peel in curly strips, often with a wintergreen scent.
ecology: Provides browse and cover; contributes to mixed-age forest structure; associates with rich herbaceous layers in northern hardwood–conifer forests.

habitat: Understory of moist northern hardwood and mixed forests, especially cool slopes and ravines.
description: An understory maple with greenish bark marked by pale vertical stripes; common in shaded WMNF woods.
ecology: Important browse for moose and deer in some areas; contributes to understory structure and microhabitat.

sources.title: UNH Extension: Northern Hardwood–Conifer Forests (mentions striped maple understory)

habitat: Cool-climate forests, swamps, ridges and ledges; can occur in subalpine zones and higher elevations.
description: A small tree with compound leaves and clusters of orange-red berries, often seen in cooler or higher WMNF settings.
ecology: Berries are important for birds (waxwings, robins, jays, grouse); twigs and foliage are browse for moose and deer.

sources.title: All About Birds: Bicknell’s Thrush habitat includes mountain-ash

habitat: Understory of cool forests, especially spruce–fir and northern hardwood–conifer forests.
description: A broad-leaved understory shrub with large leaves and flat-topped flower clusters with showy outer sterile flowers.
ecology: Provides cover and browse; flowers support pollinators; fruits are eaten by birds and mammals; important understory component in many WMNF forest types.

sources.title: UNH Extension: Lowland Spruce–Fir Forests (mentions hobblebush)

habitat: Open woods, ledges and ridges, clearings, and disturbed sites; also in subalpine settings and mountain slopes.
description: A low, colony-forming blueberry with small toothed leaves and sweet blue berries; common along sunny edges and openings in WMNF.
ecology: Important summer food for birds and mammals; responds to disturbance and can dominate in openings; contributes to berry-based food webs.

sources.title: UNH Extension: Lowland Spruce–Fir Forests (mentions blueberry understory)

habitat: Moist, cool forests, especially spruce–fir and mixed forests; common on mossy forest floors.
bloomPeriod: Late spring to early summer (berries late summer)
description: A low woodland dogwood with a whorl of leaves and small white bracts; often carpets spruce–fir forest floors.
ecology: Fruits are eaten by birds and small mammals; spreads in mats that stabilize forest-floor microhabitats in cool, moist woods.

sources.title: USFS Silvics (balsam fir associates include bunchberry)
UNH Extension: Lowland Spruce–Fir Forests (mentions bunchberry)

habitat: Forests and woodlands, including rocky slopes; common across a wide range of WMNF forest floors.
bloomPeriod: Late spring to early summer (berries summer)
description: A small forest-floor plant forming patches, with delicate white flowers and later speckled berries.
ecology: Berries are valuable to birds; often one of the earliest leaves to emerge in spring; contributes to forest-floor cover.

sources.title: UNH Extension: Hemlock-Hardwood-Pine Forests (mentions Canada mayflower)

habitat: Moist, shaded forests, commonly in northern hardwood–conifer and hemlock-associated woods.
description: A delicate woodland flower with star-shaped white blooms and a whorl of leaves near the stem tip.
ecology: Indicator of cool, moist forest-floor conditions; part of spring wildflower displays in northern forests.

sources.title: UNH Extension: Northern Hardwood–Conifer Forests (mentions starflower)
USFS Silvics (balsam fir associates include starflower)

habitat: Acidic, well-drained soils in mixed woods (often pine/hemlock) and forest edges; can occur on rocky/mossy slopes and occasionally in boggy margins.
description: A native orchid with a single pink pouch-shaped flower and two basal leaves; iconic in New England forests.
ecology: Pollinated by bees that enter the pouch and exit via a constrained route; slow to mature and sensitive to disturbance/collection.
conservationStatus: Varies by state/locality; avoid picking/collecting; some populations vulnerable due to low recruitment and habitat disturbance.

sources.title: USFS Plant of the Week: Pink lady’s slipper

habitat: Moist deciduous and mixed forests; often in rich woods and sometimes on rocky slopes.
description: A spring wildflower with three broad leaves and a single (often deep red) flower; some populations show color variation.
ecology: Fetid odor can attract fly pollinators; part of spring forest-floor displays; sensitive to trampling and over-collection in popular areas.
conservationStatus: Common regionally, but local populations can be impacted by browsing and habitat disturbance.

sources.title: USFS Plant of the Week: Red Trillium
